ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of major historical events, artists and artistic movements, philosophical perspectives, and cultural traditions in Brazil from 1500-1970. Emphasis on identification of specific names, events, places, and people with some discussion of overarching themes.
I learned Brazilian history.
I learned a lot about different parts of Brazilian culture since the Portuguese landed there and onward
I learned some pretty useful elementary Portuguese, enough to get me by should I return to Brazil anytime soon.
I really enjoyed this class. I learned so much about Brazil beyond just the surface. We delved deep into the history and culture, and I personally enjoyed learning about art, music, and literature.

I practically knew nothing about Brazilian history prior to this course, and Id suggest I now know more than the typical Brazilian! Atleast in a wider or general sense. The course explores a wide range of themes and I really enjoyed it.

During this course, I learned a lot more about the African influence in Brazilian culture today.  It was so insightful to see clear connections drawn between the arrival of African slaves in Brazil and the aspects of Brazilian culture today - whether in music, clothing, jewelry, traditions, etc.
Learned about the culture and history of Brazil

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - most required readings are primary sources or works of art; personal projects encouraged personal engagement with Brazil/Brazilians
Weaknesses - reading load was sometimes unmanageable; difficult to pay attention in lecture; readings and study guides could be better organized

Strength was the new material.
Weakness the course felt like a lecture.
Sometimes the readings felt overwhelming but David was very understanding about it and wanted us to be exposed to as much as possible

At first, I was skeptical of the strictly-lecturing method. But I ended up retaining a lot more information than I was expecting to. If the readings were shortened or the most important passages were highlighted, that would have been helpful.

The course material is a little scattered and its hard to keep up. This is more a problem of that there are too many interesting things to talk about and its hard to focus on specific moments/events/subjects without needing to discuss other culturally relevant material.

One weakness of the course was the lack of visuals during the first couple of weeks in New Haven.  I don't think that affected the quality of content or the value of the course, it was just difficult for me, as a visual learner, to catch on and keep up.
It was a lot to take in sometimes

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but only because the rest of the program is such an incredible experience. As a standalone course, no, I would not recommend it. Personally, I just wasn't as interested in an artistic and philosophical survey of five hundred years of Brazilian history. I did really enjoy when the course covered themes that were more relevant to the Brazil of today - samba, the roots of popular music, major recent historical events - but these moments were fewer than I would have preferred. I also sometimes had problems staying focused in lecture.
Yes, you must take this course to study abroad.
Yes, its a great way to get acquainted with Brazil
I would definitely recommend this course to another student to learn a new language.
Yes! I feel like my trip to Brazil was enriched by my participation in this course.
I really enjoyed this course, especially how much art and music are incorporated as part of the history.

Yes, I would!  It was a great experience.  Learning about all the influences in Brazilian culture was crucial to understanding the reality of Brazilian life and society today.  It is definitely a necessary insight.
Yes for the experience in Brazil
Definitely! A great way to learn about Brazilian culture and history while simultaneously getting to see it in present day. An absolutely wonderful opportunity.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: To be honest, I may not be able to use the knowledge and skills of this course in the future. The course did encourage meeting and talking to Brazilians through the personal project, which was useful. However, the main knowledge of the course consisted of a lot of identification of names, people, places, etc. - some of which is still relevant to modern Brazil, but a lot of which is no longer (unless Brazilian culture and history is a field of study you want to pursue.)
I will impress my friends at the dinner table.
I will apply this to other classes and share more about Brazil in my daily life
He is very knowledge about his subject, and demonstrated it well through his lectures.
After this course, I travelled around Brazil with my family, and along the way we had a couple of tour guides. I really impressed them with everything I learned in this class!
I plan on exploring the possibility of a gap year abroad in Brazil and hope to utilize the knowledge I gained to structure a project on Brazil's Escolas de Samba.
